body.script:
var siteAlerts = [{"id":3805,"title":"Coronavirus","body":"
Thursday, April 2, 2020\n
Parents, Students, and Staff\n
As things continue to evolve and change, we want to assure you that we are doing our very best to keep you up to date with any new decisions made for Maconaquah Schools. \n
Our superintendent, administrators, and school board President met this afternoon to decide how to best address the changes suggested by Governor Holcomb. As you may have heard, all Indiana schools will now run virtually for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. This means that we will utilize eLearning to complete the remainder of our school year. Students will be required to complete eLearning assignments Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays beginning April 7th and ending on May 21st.\n
With that being said, we understand that there are technology concerns as our first day of eLearning approaches. We want to again remind you that if you need technology assistance of any kind, our technology staff will be available from 9 am to 3 pm to assist students on eLearning days. Please call the help desk at 765-689-9131 ext. 5999. No student or guardian should be on school grounds without having first contacted the tech center to set up an appointment for curbside pickup.\n
We will make a plan for returning items still on school property to students at a later date. If there is something your child needs immediately (i.e. medication), please contact your building nurse. \n
Many people are verbalizing their concerns with how our school will handle the 2019-2020 graduation ceremony. At this time, Maconaquah Schools are working on how we will recognize our graduating seniors. Stay strong class of 2020, you will get through this and we will do all we can to help you and honor you for your accolades. \n
As of April 8, 2020 - Mobile Food Services\n
Our Superintendent and administrators met this afternoon to establish new guidelines for food distribution. The decision was made that for the month of April, Maconaquah School Corporation will distribute food resources to the following locations once a week: Helping Hands (176 North Broadway, Peru, IN 46970), Bunker Hill United Methodist Church (100 E Broadway, Bunker Hill, IN 46914), and Amboy Friends Church (110 E Pennsylvania St, Amboy, IN 46911). Administrative staff will reevaluate prior to the first of May to determine how we will distribute meals to our families for the remainder of the school year. \n
Hand outs for these locations are as follows:\n
Helping Hands- Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 9 a.m. to noon (Families who are not currently registered with Helping Hands must call and register prior to their first pick-up).\n
Bunker Hill United Methodist Church- Monday through Friday, noon to 12:30 p.m.\n
Amboy Friends Church- Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.\n
Additionally, we have had several questions regarding student medication, items remaining in lockers, and lunch account balances. As previously stated, all Maconaquah school buildings will be closed through the month of April. As more guidance comes, we will know whether or not essential staff will be on campus in May. At the time buildings open, administrators will meet to make a decision on how to best distribute items to students. If there is an emergency where you need an item immediately, contact your building principal. In reference to lunch account balances, there will be a school messenger email and phone call going out to parents in the next few weeks that will address this issue, so please be looking for that.\n
We want to reiterate that if any family is in dire need of assistance of any sort, please reach out to your building principal. They will assist you in whatever way possible to be sure you have the resources you need during this time. \n
Finally, we ask that you keep in mind that although Maconaquah has been leading the charge on eLearning for several years, this chapter in virtual education is brand new and will most certainly house a learning curve for both teachers and students alike. Be patient with our teaching staff, our technology department, our administrators, and your children as we all work to navigate this together. \n
Things will likely continue to change, and we will continue to update you on how Maconaquah School’s will adjust to these changes. \n
Thanks to all of those serving our community both inside the house and out. You are ALL essential in some way, and we WILL get through this TOGETHER.\n
Go Braves,\n
Jamey Callane\n
Superintendent\n
Maconaquah School Corporation\n
","dateStart":"2020-03-24T20:29:49Z","baseGroupName":"Maconaquah School Corporation","hash":"kYYCgk0ubbRlFaWEqVV3gOs4JtRJeZ0vE7ZuYL/gbho=","updateDate":"2020-04-06T20:53:07Z"}];

img.div: Inspiring and empowering our students to meet tomorrow's challenges.

h2.span: Maconaquah School Corporation Header News Feed

div.div: Under these unprecedented circumstances, we wanted to pass the information along to you regarding your child's cafeteria account.

We will be able to roll over any balance that your child has to the next school year. The balance they had before Spring break in their account is what they will begin with for the 2020-2021 school year.
If you would like to request a refund you may do so by emailing or leaving a phone message for your building bookkeeper.
** All high school seniors accounts will be automatically refunded.**
If you do not wish to keep your child's cafeteria account balance for the new school year, email or phone your request by May 8th.
YOU WILL NEED TO STATE :
* STUDENT NAME
* PARENT NAME
* MAILING ADDRESS
You do not need to take any action if you want your child's account to roll over to the next school year.
Pipe Creek - Mrs. Porter 765.473.3121 x.2015. Porterd@maconaquah.k12.in.us
Maconaquah Elementary - Mrs. Hughes 765.689.9131 x.3007. Hughesc@maconaquah.k12.in.us
Middle School - Ms. Jenkins 765.689.9131 x.4015. Jenkinsja@maconaquah.k12.in.us
High School - Miss Martin 765.689.9131 x. 5006 martinc@maconaquah.k12.in.us

div.p: MACONAQUAH SCHOOL CORPORATION BOARD OF SCHOOL TRUSTEES
Regular Board Meeting of April 22, 2020 6:00 P.M.
View our board meeting by clicking the below link and logging in with a Google account:

p.span: April 6, 2020
Maconaquah Patrons,

Our Superintendent and administrators met this afternoon to establish new guidelines for food distribution. The decision was made that for the month of April, Maconaquah School Corporation will distribute food resources to the following locations once a week:
Helping Hands (176 North Broadway, Peru, IN 46970), Bunker Hill United Methodist Church (100 E Broadway, Bunker Hill, IN 46914), and Amboy Friends Church (
110 E Pennsylvania St, Amboy, IN 46911)
. Administrative staff will reevaluate prior to the first of May to determine how we will distribute meals to our families for the remainder of the school year.
Hand outs for these locations are as follows:
Helping Hands- Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 9 a.m. to noon (Families who are not currently registered with Helping Hands must call and register prior to their first pick-up).
Bunker Hill United Methodist Church- Monday through Friday, noon to 12:30 p.m.
Amboy Friends Church- Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

Additionally, we have had several questions regarding student medication, items remaining in lockers, and lunch account balances. As previously stated, all Maconaquah school buildings will be closed through the month of April. As more guidance comes, we will know whether or not essential staff will be on campus in May. At the time buildings open, administrators will meet to make a decision on how to best distribute items to students. If there is an emergency where you need an item immediately, contact your building principal. In reference to lunch account balances, there will be a school messenger email and phone call going out to parents in the next few weeks that will address this issue, so please be looking for that.

We want to reiterate that if any family is in dire need of assistance of any sort, please reach out to your building principal. They will assist you in whatever way possible to be sure you have the resources you need during this time.
Thanks and stay safe, Braves!

div.p: Please visit our eLearning page for expectations, guidance, contact lists, and How-Tos during this time of extended time of eLearning. All technology questions, 1:1 loaners, and arrangements for computer repair and curbside pick-up should be made by calling 765-689-9131 ext. 5999.

Maconaquah Patrons,

Our Superintendent and administrators met this afternoon to establish new guidelines for food distribution. The decision was made that for the month of April, Maconaquah School Corporation will distribute food resources to the following locations once a week:

div.p: Please visit our eLearning page for expectations, guidance, contact lists, and How-Tos during this time of extended time of eLearning. All technology questions, 1:1 loaners, and arrangements for computer repair and curbside pick-up should be made by calling 765-689-9131 ext. 5999.

p.span: Thank you for taking a look at Maconaquah School Corporation!
My name is Dr. James Callane, and I am the Superintendent at Maconaquah. Over my 20 years at Maconaquah, I have learned that there is no corporation quite like it.

Maconaquah is a rural corporation that has a rich, blended history of agriculture and military influence of Grissom Air Reserve Base. The corporation serves the six southern townships of Miami County and surrounding communities, and we have four school buildings that serve our 2200+ students from preschool through 12th grade.

Pipe Creek Elementary School serves about 450 students PreK-1. Pipe Creek houses a multitude of preschool programs for varying developmental stages as well as household income levels, and it is an On My Way PreK school. It also has a STEM lab and designated STEM teacher.

Maconaquah Elementary School serves about 730 students grades 2-5. Mac El is outfitted with a STEM lab and designated STEM teacher, it became a STEM-certified school by the Indiana Department of Education in 2018, and it has been a No Excuses University School since 2014.

Maconaquah Middle School serves about 500 students grades 6-8. Mac Middle was one of the first schools in the state to become STEM-certified by the IDOE, it has partnered with Purdue University extensively to integrate STEM into all of its instruction, and it boasts an impressive Farm to School program known as “Maconaquah Cattle Company.”

Maconaquah High School serves about 640 students grades 9-12. MHS has a graduation rate of more than 95 percent, and is quite successful in academic, athletic, and art-related extracurricular activities. MHS was also rated an A school by the IDOE in 2017.

In 2011, our school became a 1:1 corporation, meaning every student became equipped with a computing device. This led to numerous corporation-wide initiatives that kept Maconaquah a cut above other school districts across the state, region, and nation. In 2014, Maconaquah was granted first privilege to utilize eLearning days in place of snow days.

The corporation also has a great relationship with the Miami County Sheriff’s Department, which partners with Maconaquah for our School Resource Officer program, and with the Indiana State Police, which is posted a few miles north of our buildings.

But what is more valuable and more important than our corporation’s many accolades is the character of our staff. In my many years as an educator and my experience as a father with two children in Maconaquah school buildings, my wife and I have never come across such caring and big-hearted individuals. Without them, our school corporation’s culture wouldn’t be nearly as nurturing as it is.
Maconaquah’s mission statement is “inspiring and empowering our students to meet tomorrow’s challenges,” and we pursue that mission with intention every day.
Thank you again, for taking a look at Maconaquah School Corporation. We hope to see you soon!
Go Braves,
Dr. James Callane
Superintendent
